climbs.name: West Face
climbs.fa: Glen Dawson and Jules Eichorn July 12, 1931

content.description: Climb the obvious chimney on the west side of the peak. At the top traverse to the left via an easy lieback on top of the crest to a broad ledge that ends at small gap and a wall. Downclimb the chimney at this wall and do an exposed walk next to the wall on the west side leading to the notch between the two summit towers. Climb the tower to the right(East) onto the exposed true summit fin.
content.location: From Tuolumne Meadows hike in via Cathedral Lakes Trail, Budd Lake Trail, or Lake Elizabeth Trail. Easy cross country once in the vicinity of Unicorn Peak or Echo Peaks.

content.description: This route climbs weaknesses in the northeast Arete and then circles around the west side of the west tower back to the notch between the 2 summit towers. Climb up onto the higher eastern summit from here.
content.protection: Solo or a light alpine rack.
content.location: Best approached from the Lake Elizabeth Trail from Tuolumne Meadows. Love the trail at the lake and climb east slopes the to ridgeline between Cockscomb and Unicorn Peak.

content.description: I figured Cockscomb should get a description on a fun way to get to the summit. There are crack systems to take up once you're at the gravel/scree field. Follow path of least resistance to the summit. I felt it was mostly easy 5th with 1 or 2 5.7 moves.
content.protection: Solo or standard rack I suppose
content.location: Approach from unicorn or Echo. If approaching from unicorn you'll see the scree field and obvious crack systems. If coming from Echo come around the corner avoiding the 4th class way up.

climbs.name: East Face of South Tower
climbs.fa: Rick Cashner and Alan Swanson, September 1987

content.description: Begin by climbing a knobby, 5.10a crack to a pedestal. The second pitch follows a wide, curved crack to the summit bulge. Overcome the bulge by means of a thin 5.9 crack.
content.location: Same approach as other climbs on the East side of Cockscomb.

climbs.name: East Face
climbs.fa: Descended July 12, 1931, by Glen Dawson and Jules Eichorn. First ascent October 1983 by David Harden.

content.description: This one-pitch route follows an obvious corner system that rises above the highest trees.
content.location: Same approach as other climbs on the east side of Cockscomb.

content.description: This route begins by climbing up the series of slabs on the northeast face directly under a large chimney. Once just below the easier looking chimney, traverse up and left across steepening darker slabs to a 5.7 handcrack near the wall on the southside of the steepening gully. Climb this up to the ledge directly below the west summit. From here climb the 5.7+ offwidth up to a hand traverse left(east) into the notch between the two summits. The hand traverse can be protected with a BD#3. A giant horn on the east side of the west summit tower can be slung to bring up your second. Downclimb the west summit and climb unprotected 4th class up to the east true summit from here.
content.protection: Cams: doubles BD#0.5-3, set of nuts, 60m rope
content.location: This route is best approached from Tuolumne Meadows via the Lake Elizabeth Trail. Leave the trail at the lake and head up easy cross country to the ridge connecting Cockscomb and Unicorn Peak.
